children.value: Woot! You have mastered Discordeno inhibitors already. Now it's time to finally make our bot multi-lingual. Vàmanos!

A Discordeno language is a folder that will hold all our responses that the bot sends. By having various different language files you can have a multi-lingual bot that can be used in different languages.
By default, Discordeno comes built with support for i18next(one of if not the best localization libraries). If you want to learn more, go to
. For now, there is probably not going to be anything you will need to learn there. As most of the functionality has already been created for you right here in Discordeno.
The default language with Discordeno is American English which uses the name
folder you will find a folder called
. This is where all the strings can be kept for your bot that can be easily translated by other translators.
The first folder inside the languages folder must be a language folder following the name pattern like
. So for example, if we wanted to add a Spanish(Spain) language to our bot we would create a new folder called
You can have as many folder in here as you like. For example I can do something like
. Notice that I have created categories to help keep them categorized and easier to find. You can do it however you wish to have them. For now, just remember that files must always be
Earlier in the guide, we made a hug command. So let's make that commands translations work properly now.
Most of the time, you should start with this base. The
key, is used in the help command and provides the description for the command. When someone types
they would see this description you typed.
In our hug command we also had 2 other keys we used.
is pretty easy to understand but the
has some interesting things in it so let's jump into that.
Discordeno provides you a built in function called
the id of the server. This is used to determine which language to use.
the unique folderpath:KEY string that will determine which string to translate.
the variables that the strings have available to them.
i18next allows you to pass in variables that you can use when you want in your strings. If you recall from our guide ealier we passed in 2 variables.

translate(
	message.guildID,
	`commands/fun/${data.name}:${type}`,
	{ mention: message.member()!.mention, user: member.mention },
)
Here we can see that we passed in:
: The user mention who used this command.
: The user mention of the member who was @ by the command author.
When you create keys in the files there are a couple rules to follow.
The first one is the only one that is mandatory. The other two are recommended for you.

Every developer forgets stuff sometimes. When you forget to translate a key, it will be marked as a missing key and you will be alerted. If you provided a channelID in the configs file, you be be sent a message there and it will also be logged in your console.
Let's just create a spanish version of the hug command from above to see an example of different languages.
Notice, that there are 2 thing that were
. These 2 things should never be translated. Anything else can be translated upon your needs.
i18next works perfectly with localization platforms. For example, you can easily plug in
This is the one I use in my bot but you can use anything you like.
Wow! You have even masted languages. Go ahead and jump back to the role command we made earlier and add translation support to it. Give it some love!
Once you are ready, let's go make our first monitor.
